questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room with a single seizure-like episode. One parent states the patient started contracting his upper and lower extremities for 30 seconds. His parents state he has had several behavioral complaints at preschool over the past few months. He was able to walk without support until several weeks ago, when they noticed that he had an unsteady gait while walking. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 124/min and blood pressure is 110/85 mmHg. The patient is awake but lethargic. Neurological examination reveals symmetric peripheral neuropathy with diminished sensation to pain and absent deep tendon reflexes. Fundoscopy reveals optic atrophy. Motor examination reveals hypotonia and extensor plantar responses bilaterally. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. He says one and two-word phrases but is unable to speak in complete sentences. MRI of the brain reveals hyperintensities in the periventricular regions of the brain matter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of recent onset unsteady gait, neurodegeneration, and regression of milestones has now presented with a seizure episode. This presentation is suggestive of metachromatic leukodystrophy.

Metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD) is an inborn error of metabolism resulting in the deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase and is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Genetic testing (DNA sequencing) should be offered if either parent has a family history of MLD or are members of susceptible populations, such as Ashkanazi Jews, Cajun and Amish populations.

 


MLD can result in central and peripheral demyelination as a result of accumulation of sulfatides, such as cerebroside sulfate. Initial symptoms can manifest with unsteadiness while walking, peripheral neuropathy, developmental delay, regression of previously attained developmental milestones, and poor school performance. With progression of the disease, spasticity, optic atrophy, seizures and profound intellectual disability can occur.





Clinical phenotypes can involve late infantile onset, juvenile onset, and adult onset. A typical clinical picture with an MRI showing evidence of hyperintensities in the periventricular area is suggestive of a diagnosis of MLD. Additional investigations, particularly in the juvenile and adult stages, include reduced nerve conduction velocity and CSF protein concentrations. Confirmation of MLD is made by detecting reduced activity of arylsulfatase in leukocytes or fibroblasts from serum samples. Histopathological examination may reveal metachromatic granules in the tissue specimen. In the nervous system, the loss of myelinated oligodendrocytes can be seen. Currently, curative treatment for MLD does not exist.




Option Analysis

✅ Metachromatic dystrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Multiple sclerosis :
Incorrect: Multiple sclerosis is characterized by neurological deficits disseminated in time and space. It most commonly occurs in women, with the mean clinical age of onset ranging from 28-31 years of age. Although it can present radiologically with hyperintensities in the periventricular regions of the brain, considering this patient’s age and regression of developmental milestones, this diagnosis is unlikely.
❌ Hunter disease:
Incorrect: The presentation of Hunter disease includes developmental delay, coarse facial features, and recurrent airway infections. In most cases, abdominal examination will reveal hepatosplenomegaly. Abdominal examination in this patient was unremarkable, and his neurological and ophthalmic examinations suggest a different diagnosis.
❌ Fabry disease:
Incorrect: Fabry disease can result in peripheral neuropathy (neuropathic pain), angiokeratomas, telangiectasias and hypohidrosis. Dementia and neurodevelopmental regression are not classically seen. The absence of these dermatological findings makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Tay-Sachs disease:
Incorrect: Tay-Sachs is liposomal storage disorder that results in neurodevelopmental delay. A cherry-red spot on the macula is typically noted on fundoscopy. Optic atrophy and MRI findings with hyperintensities in the periventricular regions of the brain are not characteristic of this disease.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for evaluation of abnormal development and poor performance at school. The child is currently seeing an ophthalmologist for evaluation of poor vision. The parents state the child has had difficulty walking on her own over the past few months, and they have noted a curvature to her spine causing her to walk with a “hunched back.” The patient has a history of multiple sinus and respiratory infections over the past 2 years, requiring antibiotics for treatment. The family is part of an Amish community. Head circumference is above the 95th percentile. Facial features are notable for a prominent forehead, flat nose bridge and enlarged lips, gums, and tongue. Abdominal examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and an umbilical hernia. Ophthalmic examination reveals corneal clouding. Fundoscopic examination reveals optic atrophy.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, coarse facial features, and visual disturbances. This presentation is consistent with a diagnosis of Hurler syndrome, an autosomal recessive mucopolysaccharidosis.

Normally, the enzyme alpha-L-iduronidase is responsible for degradation of glycosaminoglycans (GAG or mucopolysaccharides). Impaired metabolism of these cell components in Hurler syndrome leads to accumulation of large amounts of GAG in the body, eventually causing various cells to become severely dysfunctional, leading to cell death. The deposition of GAG causes enlargement and thickening of multiple organs such as the heart, spleen, liver, muscles, joints, and the central nervous system, causing severe functional impairment. Histopathology of affected organs typically reveals Hurler cells, which are characterized by an increased abundance of lysosomes and an abnormal lysosomal morphology due to GAG accumulation.

 Most patients with Hurler syndrome begin to develop the characteristic facies within the first year of life, which includes a constellation of features known as coarse facial features (e.g., prominent forehead, flat nasal bridge, enlarged tongue). Development peaks at 2-5 years of age and then progressively begins to decline. Accumulation of glycosaminoglycans leads to structural changes in the cornea (leading to progressive vision loss), as well as soft tissue of the nose and throat. Complications include airway obstruction, recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, joint deformities (dysostosis multiplex), blindness and neurological decline. Lifespan is markedly shortened in Hurler syndrome. The average age at death is 5 years, and nearly all patients die before 10 years of age.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Hurler syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hunter syndrome:
Incorrect: Hunter syndrome is a lysosomal storage disorder that results in the accumulation of the glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate. However, corneal clouding and impaired vision is more likely to be associated with Hurler syndrome. Furthermore, Hunter syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder, making it highly unlikely to be present in this young girl. 
❌ Tay-Sachs disease:
Incorrect: Tay-Sachs is characterized by hepatosplenomegaly, neurodegeneration, and developmental delay. However, fundoscopy findings would reveal a cherry-red spot on the macula, which is not seen in this patient.
❌ Gaucher disease:
Incorrect: Gaucher disease does cause hepatosplenomegaly. Additionally, skeletal abnormalities including osteoporosis and avascular necrosis of the femur are also seen. The absence of these findings makes this diagnosis unlikely. The coarse facial features described in this patient (e.g., large, bulging head, flat nasal bridge, macroglossia) are more likely to be associated with Hurler syndrome.
❌ Niemann-Pick disease:
Incorrect: Niemann-Pick disease presents with hepatosplenomegaly and progressive neurodegeneration. However, fundoscopic examination is likely to exhibit a cherry-red spot on the macula.

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant is brought to a pediatrician for evaluation of failure to thrive. The patient was recently adopted and has never been evaluated by a physician as far as the new parents are aware. According to the parents, the infant cannot grab objects or roll from a prone to supine position. He has also experienced several episodes of generalized seizure activity. He is at the 10th percentile for length and 5th percentile for weight. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 80/53 mmHg, and pulse is 92/min. Upon physical examination, the patient has a weak cry and diffuse hypotonia. Hepatomegaly is present with abdominal palpation. Genetic analysis reveals a mutation in the PEX gene. The organelle affected in this patient's condition is normally involved in which of the following cellular processes?

choices.text: Modification of proteins targeted for lysosomal degradation
Clearance of bronchopulmonary secretions via ciliary oscillations
Synthesis of ATP via oxidative phosphorylation

questions.solution:
This young child presents with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and a history of seizures. Genetic testing reveals a PEX gene mutation. Together, these findings are consistent with Zellweger syndrome–a disease that occurs secondary to peroxisomal defects.

Peroxisomes are membrane-bound organelles involved in several critical cellular processes, including:

1. Neutralization of free radicals, which in turn protects cellular components such as DNA, lipids, and proteins from oxidative damage.
2. Breakdown of toxic substances including ethanol and formaldehyde. This process is performed by catalase and also helps convert H2O2 into water.
3. ɑ-oxidation, where branched-chain fatty acids are broken down into linear fatty acids.
4. β-oxidation, where linear very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) and medium-chain fatty acids (MCFAs) are enzymatically broken down into progressively smaller chains.
5. Breakdown of amino acids
6. Synthesis of bile acids, cholesterol, and plasmalogens.



Option Analysis

✅ ɑ-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Modification of proteins targeted for lysosomal degradation:
Incorrect: The Golgi body is responsible for adding mannose-6-phosphate residues to proteins targeted for lysosomal degradation. In I-cell disease, the Golgi body fails to phosphorylate mannose residues, and proteins are secreted into the extracellular space. Patients with I-cell disease often present with coarse facial features, restricted joint mobility, and skeletal abnormalities. This disease is not associated with a PEX gene mutation.  
❌ Clearance of bronchopulmonary secretions via ciliary oscillations:
Incorrect: Cilia assist in clearing bronchopulmonary secretions. Primary ciliary dyskinesia is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by immotile cilia. Patients are at risk of airway disease due to impaired mucociliary clearance. Around 50% of patients with this condition also have situs inversus. The patient in this vignette does not have a history of recurrent pulmonary infections.  
❌ Synthesis of amino acid chains:
Incorrect: Ribosomes synthesize amino acid chains from mRNA. However, this patient is presenting with hypotonia, seizures, hepatomegaly, and a mutation in the PEX gene, which is more concerning for Zellweger disease – a peroxisomal disorder.  
❌ Synthesis of ATP via oxidative phosphorylation:
Incorrect: The mitochondria contain the enzymes comprising the electron transport chain involved in synthesizing ATP via oxidative phosphorylation. Mitochondrial abnormalities can lead to myopathies and optic neuropathy. However, this patient is presenting with hypotonia, seizures, hepatomegaly, and a mutation in the PEX gene, which is more concerning for Zellweger disease – a peroxisomal disorder.

questions.text: A 14-year old girl is brought to the clinic for evaluation of difficulty walking. Her parents state that she has become increasingly uncoordinated over the past several months, but she was previously walking normally. They also note that her skin is very dry, and she seems to have difficulty seeing at night. Her siblings do not have similar symptoms. On physical exam, the patient’s skin appears dry, and there is shortening of the bilateral 4th toes. Neurological exam is significant for ataxia. She is subsequently found to have a mutation in the PHYH gene. Metabolism of which of the following compounds is aberrant in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Peroxisomal disorders are a heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by dysfunction of peroxisomes. Peroxisomes are ubiquitous organelles responsible for β-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) and ɑ-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. They also function in the catabolism of amino acids and alcohol, as well as the synthesis of bile acids, cholesterol, and plasmalogens. Peroxisomal disorders include Zellweger syndrome, Refsum disease, and adrenoleukodystrophy.

Refsum disease is an autosomal recessive disorder of ɑ-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids in peroxisomes. It is caused by mutations in the PHYH gene, which impairs metabolism of phytanic acid to pristanic acid. Patients present in childhood or adolescence with scaly skin, ataxia, cataracts, night blindness, sensorineural hearing loss, shortening of the 4th toes, and epiphyseal dysplasia. Refsum disease is diagnosed by the presence of an elevated serum phytanic acid level and genetic testing. Treatment consists of dietary restriction and plasmapheresis.

Option Analysis

❌ Short-chain fatty acids:
Incorrect: Short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (SCAD) is a rare disorder caused by mutations in the ACADS gene, which results in accumulation of short-chain fatty acids and ammonia. Patients with this disease present with developmental delay and poor growth. This patient has Refsum syndrome, which is instead a defect in ɑ-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids.  
❌ Medium-chain fatty acids:
Incorrect: Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCADD) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder which results in accumulation of medium-chain fatty acids. These patients present with episodes of hypoketotic hypoglycemia, vomiting, and lethargy. This patient has Refsum syndrome, which is instead a defect in ɑ-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids.  
❌ Long-chain fatty acids:
Incorrect: Systemic primary carnitine deficiency occurs due to a lack of cellular uptake of carnitine and subsequent absence of transport of long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) into the mitochondria. Accumulation of LCFAs in the cytoplasm leads to weakness, hypotonia, hypoketotic hypoglycemia, and dilated cardiomegaly. This patient has Refsum syndrome, which is instead a defect in ɑ-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids.  
❌ Very-long-chain fatty acids:
Incorrect: Adrenoleukodystrophy results from X-linked recessive mutations in the ABCD1 gene and defects in B-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCF). VLCF accumulates in the adrenal glands, brain matter, and testes, which can eventually cause adrenal crisis, coma, and death. This patient has Refsum syndrome, which is instead a defect in ɑ-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids.  
✅ Branched-chain fatty acids  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy is brought to the pediatric emergency department for evaluation of productive cough and fever. The patient has had multiple prior emergency department visits due to similar symptoms, which resolved with high-dose antibiotic therapy. He was born at 38-weeks gestational age via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery to a 30-year-old woman. Family history is significant for similar symptoms in the patient’s older sister. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg. Physical examination reveals an ill-appearing child with mildly enlarged tonsils without erythema or exudates. Bilateral rales and rhonchi are heard on lung auscultation, and the point of maximal impulse is displaced to the right side of the chest. A chest CT shows bilateral hyperinflation of lungs and significant peribronchial thickening. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Impaired formation of membrane attack complex

questions.solution:
This patient has recurrent sinopulmonary infections, peribronchial thickening on CT imaging, and displaced point of maximal impulse. These findings are suggestive of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD).

PCD is a rare, autosomal recessive genetic disorder that causes reduced motility of the cilia lining the respiratory tract and fallopian tubes, as well as the flagella of sperm cells. The defect occurs due to a mutation in dynein, which is a ciliary motor protein. PCD can manifest with impaired mucociliary clearance, recurrent sinopulmonary infections (e.g., pneumonia, bronchiectasis, otitis media), infertility, and increased risk of ectopic pregnancy. Furthermore, some patients may have situs inversus, which is when the orientation of internal organs is reversed.

Some patients with PCD may present with the triad of chronic sinusitis, situs inversus, and bronchiectasis. This constellation of symptoms is termed Kartagner syndrome.

Patients with PCD have decreased nasal nitric oxide, and this finding can be used as a screening test. However, visualization of immotile cilia via techniques such as electron microscopy or high-speed video microscopy is generally required to confirm the diagnosis.



Option Analysis

❌ Impaired synthesis of pulmonary surfactant:
Incorrect: Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) arises due to inadequate synthesis of pulmonary surfactant. It can manifest in preterm infants or in infants born to mothers with diabetes mellitus. Patients can present with dyspnea, tachypnea, and cyanosis shortly after birth. In contrast, this patient was born full-term, making NRDS unlikely.
✅ Abnormal cilia motility:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Defective epithelial cell chloride channels:
Incorrect: Defective epithelial cell chloride channels are characteristic of cystic fibrosis. Although patients with cystic fibrosis can also present with recurrent sinopulmonary infections, the condition would not typically manifest with dextrocardia.
❌ Impaired formation of membrane attack complex:
Incorrect: A deficiency of terminal complement cofactors C5-C9 can result in impaired formation of the membrane attack complex. Affected patients are susceptible to Neisseria infection. The condition, however, would not typically cause recurrent sinopulmonary infections or dextrocardia.
❌ NADPH oxidase deficiency:
Incorrect: A deficiency of NADPH oxidase results in chronic granulomatous disease, which is characterized by an inability of phagocytes to produce hydrogen peroxide in their lysosomes. Patients can present with recurrent pyogenic infections and infections by catalase positive organisms (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Aspergillus). However, dextrocardia in combination with recurrent sinopulmonary infections is more consistent with the presentation of primary ciliary dyskinesia.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of developmental delay. The child is breastfed, but the mother states that recently, he has been irritable and frequently has been having feeding difficulties. His parents have noticed that he is unable to roll over, while his older brother was able to sit up unassisted at the same age. He is of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Vitals are within normal limits. Facial examination reveals no structural abnormalities. Neurological examination reveals symmetric peripheral neuropathy with diminished sensation to pain. Motor examination reveals spasticity, and muscle atrophy is noted in all extremities. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Fundoscopy reveals optic atrophy. The family is instructed to return for further genetic testing; however, they are lost to follow-up. One year later, the child passes away due to aspiration pneumonia. Autopsy specimens reveal neural tissue with multinucleated macrophages that stain positive with Periodic acid–Schiff stain with widespread demyelinating changes. Accumulation of which of the following metabolites was responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with physical examination findings of peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, developmental delay, and Periodic acid–Schiff stain (PAS) positive globoid cells in the central nervous tissue has a presentation consistent with Krabbe disease.



By Jensflorian - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0,
Reproduced from Wikimedia commons

Krabbe disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactocerebrosidase resulting in the accumulation of galactocerebroside and its toxic breakdown product galactosylsphingosine (psychosine), which causes demyelination in the central and peripheral nervous system.

Most patients with Krabbe disease present within the first 12 months of life. In most cases, the prognosis is poor, and the disease is progressive. Clinical manifestations of Krabbe disease include irritability, difficulty feeding, regression of developmental milestones, peripheral neuropathy, spasticity and muscle atrophy.

Diagnosis of Krabbe disease is made by estimating the activity of galactocerebrosidase in leukocytes isolated from whole blood. Pathological evidence of Krabbe disease can be found in the central and peripheral nervous system and includes globoid cells, which are lipid-laden macrophages that stain positively with PAS, as well as widespread demyelination. There is no curative treatment, and management is largely supportive.




Option Analysis

✅ Galactocerebroside:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Glucocerebroside:
Incorrect: Glucocerebroside is the substrate that accumulates in the liver and bone marrow in Gaucher disease. The characteristic cells found on tissue analysis in Gaucher disease are Gaucher cells, which are lipid-laden macrophages that appear like “crumpled tissue paper” on histological examination.
❌ Heparan sulfate:
Incorrect: Heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate are glycosaminoglycans that accumulate in Hunter syndrome, which is characterized by coarse facial features, developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly.
❌ Sphingomyelin :
Incorrect: Niemann-Pick results in the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the liver and neural tissue, which presents as clusters of foam cells. In most cases, hepatosplenomegaly is noted. The absence of these findings makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ GM2 ganglioside:
Incorrect: Deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase results in the accumulation of the substrate GM2 ganglioside and the clinical manifestations of Tay-Sachs disease, which include developmental delay, neurodegeneration and a cherry-red spot in the macula. Peripheral neuropathy and optic atrophy would not be expected. On histological analysis, Tay-Sachs is likely to exhibit lysosomes with onion skin appearance, not PAS-positive globoid cells as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of increasing head size and difficulties at school. The patient has had trouble interacting with his peers and is unable to communicate with full sentences. His teacher has reported several episodes of aggressive behavior towards other students as well. His birth was unremarkable, and he started walking at the age of 15 months. His parents have noticed that he tends to walk with an unsteady gait over the last month. His past medical history is significant for recurrent upper respiratory infections since the age of 8 months. Vitals are within normal limits. Weight and height are tracking at the 30th percentile, but head circumference is above the 90th percentile. His facial features are notable for a prominent forehead, flat nose bridge and enlarged lips, gums and tongue. Echocardiogram reveals left ventricular hypertrophy. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and an umbilical hernia. Ophthalmic examination is normal.  Accumulation of which of the following metabolites is responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Hunter syndrome is an X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disorder that results in the accumulation of the glycosaminoglycans, heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate due to a deficiency of the iduronate 2-sulfatase enzyme. Widespread accumulation of these glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) leads to cellular injury resulting in organ failure.

Patients affected by Hunter disease can have neurologic deficits, developmental delays, macrocephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, and cardiac involvement (arrhythmias, left ventricular hypertrophy). Most children are unaffected at birth and gradually develop the characteristic facial features (e.g., prominent forehead, flat nasal bridge, enlarged tongue) seen in Hunter syndrome by 2-4 years of age. These coarse facial features are red flags for early diagnosis. Another characteristic early sign is an increasing head size due to the development of hydrocephalus from excessive GAGs depositing in the meninges and spinal cord, resulting in obstruction of CSF.

Common abdominal manifestations include hepatosplenomegaly, due to accumulation of GAG in visceral tissue, and umbilical hernias. Recurrent otitis media and other upper respiratory symptoms can occur due to GAG accumulation within the soft tissue of the respiratory tract. Skeletal involvement can manifest as carpal tunnel syndrome, joint stiffness and evidence of dysostosis on radiographs.

Early initiation of enzyme replacement therapy has been found to be beneficial. However, there is no curative treatment.

Although Hunter syndrome and Hurler syndrome share common clinical characteristics, distinctive features that are seen with Hunter syndrome include pearly skin papules and the absence of corneal clouding. Furthermore, Hunter syndrome demonstrates an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, whereas Hurler syndrome has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.




Option Analysis

✅ Heparan sulfate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Limit dextrans :
Incorrect: Deficiency of debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase) results in a glycogen storage disease (Cori disease) that leads to the accumulation of limit dextran-like structures in the cytosol of cells. Patients with Cori disease present with hepatomegaly and ketotic hypoglycemia. The coarse facial features and developmental delay as seen in this patient are not typically found in Cori disease.
❌ Galactose :
Incorrect: Galactokinase deficiency results in the accumulation of galactose, as galactose is not phosphorylated to galactose-1-phosphate. Excess galactose is converted to galactitol, an osmotic agent that causes neonatal cataracts. Galactosemia is not associated with developmental delay, left ventricular hypertrophy, or splenomegaly. Additionally, ophthalmic examination was unremarkable in this patient.
❌ Glycogen in lysosomes:
Incorrect: Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disorder that results in the accumulation of glycogen specifically in lysosomes. It occurs due to a deficiency of acid glucosidase, an enzyme responsible for breaking down glycogen in the acidic environment of the lysosomes. The classical symptoms present in infancy and include hepatomegaly, hypotonia, and cardiomegaly. This patient’s coarse facial features and developmental delay suggest an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Sphingomyelin :
Incorrect: Niemann-Pick disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder that results in the accumulation of sphingomyelin. Clinical manifestations include hepatosplenomegaly, progressive neurodegeneration, and a cherry red spot in the macula.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to an outpatient clinic to establish care. The patient has not seen a physician in several years but overall feels healthy except for blurry vision. She attributes this symptom to myopia caused by “spending too many hours in front of the laptop.” Past medical history is significant for pelvic inflammatory disease successfully treated with antibiotics. The patient was adopted as a young child and has never met her biological parents. Vitals are within normal limits. Slit-lamp examination is notable for bilateral upward lens subluxation. Physical examination reveals a patient at the 90th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. The patient also has long, tapering fingers and a prominent, protruding sternum. Oropharyngeal examination shows a high-arched palate with crowded teeth. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with tall stature, upward lens subluxation, and pectus carinatum. She likely has Marfan syndrome, which is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene (FBN1) on chromosome 15.

Patients with Marfan syndrome can present with musculoskeletal, ocular, and cardiovascular symptoms. Musculoskeletal symptoms include Marfanoid body habitus (e.g., tall stature, long extremities), joint hypermobility, as well as pectus excavatum or carinatum.

Patients can also experience cardiovascular symptoms such as aortic aneurysm formation, aortic dissection, and mitral valve prolapse. These symptoms arise since the defect in fibrillin causes weakening of connective tissue in the ascending aorta (cystic medial degeneration). Eye involvement can cause upward and outward lens subluxation. Furthermore, Marfan syndrome can cause stretch marks on the skin and bullae in the lungs.

Homocystineuria, a rare metabolic disorder, also presents with Marfanoid body habitus. However, homocystinuria can be distinguished via the unique features of fair complexion, intellectual disability, downward and medial lens subluxation, and increased risk of thromboembolic events.





Option Analysis

❌ Osteoporotic fracture:
Incorrect: Patients with Klinefelter syndrome are at risk for osteoprotic fracture due to estrogen deficiency resulting from ovarian dysgenesis. In contrast, this patient has lens subluxation, tall stature, and pectus carinatum, which are more suggestive of Marfan syndrome.
✅ Aortic dissection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thromboembolic stroke:
Incorrect: Homocystinuria presents with many features that overlap with Marfan syndrome. However, patients with homocystinuria also tend to have fair complexion, intellectual disability, downward lens subluxation, and increased risk of thromboembolic events. In contrast, this patient has upward subluxation of the lens, which is more suggestive of Marfan syndrome. Marfan syndrome is not associated with an increased risk of thromboembolic strokes.
❌ Alveolar hemorrhages:
Incorrect: Alveolar hemorrhages can be caused by autoimmune conditions (e.g., ANCA-associated vasculitis, systemic lupus erythematosus, Goodpasture syndrome). In contrast, Marfan syndrome is not associated with alveolar hemorrhages.
❌ Carpal tunnel syndrome:
Incorrect: Carpal tunnel syndrome can be due to autoimmune conditions (e.g. rheumatoid arthritis) and endocrinopathies (e.g., hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus). This patient has upwards lens subluxation, tall stature, and pectus carinatum, which are suggestive of Marfan syndrome. Marfan syndrome is not associated with carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text: An 8-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a seizure-like episode. The parents state the patient started contracting her upper and lower extremities for 30 seconds. Her mother has noticed she has been having difficulty feeding over the past several weeks due to an inability to suckle. Her parents state she was able to sit up on her own without support until a month ago, when they noticed that she could no longer sit up or roll over. Her birth was unremarkable. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 135/min and blood pressure is 94/84.  Motor examination reveals hypotonia in all 4 limbs, as well as increased intensity of deep tendon reflexes in all extremities. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Bilateral fundoscopic examination reveals a bright reddish area at the center of macula surrounded by retinal opacification. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient described in the clinical vignette with regression of motor milestones, hypotonia, hyperreflexia, and a cherry-red macula on eye examination has features that are suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease.

Tay-Sachs disease (TSD) is a lysosomal storage disorder that is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Genetic testing (DNA sequencing) should be offered if either partner has a family history of Tay-Sachs disease or are members of susceptible populations, such as Ashkanazi Jews, Cajun and Amish populations.

 


TSD is a neurodegenerative disease that results from the deficient functioning of the enzyme hexosaminidase A that leads to the accumulation of the metabolic product GM2 ganglioside within cell lysosomes. Neuronal cells are particularly susceptible to GM2 ganglioside, and most clinical findings stem from the accumulation of this storage material. On histologic examination, neurons are ballooned with cytoplasmic vacuoles, which constitute distended lysosomes with ganglioside. On electron microscopy, the most prominent feature seen is a whorled configuration within lysosomes resembling “onion-skin layers.”

TSD exists in two clinical phenotypes; the classic, infantile form and the late onset form. In the infantile form, most children born with TSD have normal motor development in the first couple of months of life. Then, in the first 3-5 months, they begin to demonstrate regression of milestones that they previously attained.  Physical examination findings include macrocephaly, hypotonia, hyperreflexia, blindness and spasticity. One of the characteristic fundoscopy findings include a cherry-red spot at the macula. Mental deterioration and motor dysfunction is progressive and offers a poor prognosis. Complications include seizures, pneumonia and issues with feeding. Most patients suffering from the infantile form of Tay Sachs have a life expectancy of 2-5 years of age.

In the late onset form, symptoms are less progressive and may become evident anytime between adolescence and mid-to-late 30’s.




Diagnosis is made with estimation of hexosaminidase A activity in leukocytes, serum and other body fluids. Management is predominantly directed towards supportive care. There is no known treatment currently.




Option Analysis

✅ Tay-Sachs disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fabry disease:
Incorrect: Fabry disease results from the accumulation of ceramide trihexoside due to deficiency of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase. It is characterized by peripheral neuropathy and dermatological manifestations like angiokeratomas and hypohidrosis. Developmental delay and seizures are not likely.
❌ Hunter syndrome:
Incorrect: Hunter syndrome does present with developmental delay. However, abdominal examination will reveal hepatosplenomegaly and abdominal defects. It results from the accumulation of heparan sulfate due to a deficiency in the enzyme iduronate-2-sulfatase.
❌ Niemann-Pick disease:
Incorrect: The presentation of Niemann-Pick disease and Tay-Sachs disease is very similar (e.g., hypotonia, cherry-red macula), although there are a few key differentiating factors. Niemann-Pick is characterized by hepatosplenomegaly (which is not seen in Tay-Sachs), as well as hyporeflexia (in contrast to hyperreflexia that is seen in Tay-Sachs). Niemann-Pick disease results from the deficient functioning of the enzyme sphingomyelinase.
❌ Metachromatic leukodystrophy:
Incorrect: Metachromatic dystrophy is a central and peripheral demyelinating disease resulting in ataxia and dementia. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase, resulting in accumulation of the enzyme cerebroside sulfate.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the office with his parent because of blurry vision, which has been ongoing for the past several months. The patient has had increasing difficulty seeing the board from the back of the classroom at school. He is otherwise healthy and enjoys playing basketball. Past medical history is significant for scoliosis, for which he wears a back brace and regularly follows-up with an orthopedic surgeon. Family history is significant for a history of aortic valve replacement in the patient’s father last year. Vitals are within normal limits. Slit-lamp examination shows bilateral upward lens subluxation. Physical examination reveals a patient at the 95th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight, with long arms and legs, thin fingers, and a prominent, protruding sternum. A diastolic murmur is auscultated over the right upper sternal border. This patient most likely has an inherited defect in the gene encoding for which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with tall stature, upward lens subluxation, scoliosis, pectus carinatum, and a family history of aortic valve replacement. These symptoms are suggestive of Marfan syndrome.

Marfan syndrome is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene on chromosome 15. This gene encodes the fibrillin-1 protein, which is a glycoprotein component of microfibrils that forms a sheath around elastin fibers. Fibrillin in the extracellular space acts as a scaffold for additional proteins like elastin, which are highly cross-linked, and allows tissues to stretch and then spring back to their original shape. In Marfan syndrome, fibrillin-1 is either less abundant or is dysfunctional. As a result, there are fewer functioning microfibrils in the extracellular matrix, meaning there is less tissue integrity and elasticity.

Patients classically present with musculoskeletal symptoms such as tall stature, long extremities, hypermobile joints, and pectus carinatum or excavatum. Patients can also have ocular symptoms secondary to subluxation of the lens, which is typically displaced superiorly and temporally. Finally, patients can experience cardiovascular symptoms such as aortic regurgitation, aortic necrosis, and mitral valve prolapse. 

Option Analysis

❌ Type I collagen:
Incorrect: Osteogenesis imperfecta is a connective tissue disorder that results from mutations in the type I collagen genes (e.g., COL1A1, COL1A2). It can present with fractures after minor trauma, blue sclera, hearing loss, and dentinogenesis imperfecta. Patients with this disorder do not usually have tall stature, lens dislocation, or pectus carinatum.
❌ Dystrophin:
Incorrect: Mutations in the dystrophin gene can lead to muscular dystrophies, such as Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy. Patients can present with delayed motor development (e.g., taking longer to learn to sit, stand, or walk) and enlarged calf muscles (pseudohypertrophy) secondary to replacement of muscle tissue by fatty tissue. However, this patient’s tall stature, lens dislocation, and pectus carinatum are more concerning for Marfan syndrome.
✅ Fibrillin-1:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fragile X mental retardation protein:
Incorrect: A mutation in the gene encoding for fragile X mental retardation protein results in fragile X syndrome, which is characterized by macroorchidism, intellectual disability, autism-like behavior, and a large jaw. In contrast, this patient’s tall stature, lens dislocation, pectus carinatum, and aortic murmur are more concerning for Marfan syndrome.
❌ Hamartin:
Incorrect: Tuberous sclerosis can develop in patients with hamartin (TSC1 and TSC2) gene mutation. The condition can cause cardiac rhabdomyomas, central nervous system hamartomas, renal cysts, Ash leaf spots, and facial angiofibromas. This condition does not cause lens dislocation or disportionately tall stature.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with skin lesions that his parent noticed last week while they were out swimming. His parent notes that while his siblings typically sweat while playing outside, he rarely sweats, and his shirts are almost always dry, even after strenuous exercise. The patient has also complained of pain in his arms and legs, particularly in the heat, over the past month. He occasionally complains of intermittent, severe abdominal pain. His birth was unremarkable and he has attained all his developmental milestones. His family is of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Vitals are within normal limits. Skin examination reveals erythematous macules around the umbilicus and groin area.

 
Reproduced from Wikipedia

Neurological examination reveals symmetric peripheral neuropathy with diminished sensation to touch and temperature. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Complete blood count is normal. A genetic disorder is suspected. If further testing is performed, which of the following enzymes is most likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a presentation suggestive of Fabry disease, an X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disorder. This disease results from the deficiency of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase A, resulting in the accumulation of the substrate ceramide trihexoside/globotriaosylceramide.




Clinical manifestations of Fabry disease can present in early childhood and, in some cases, can present as late as the early 30’s. Initial presentations can manifest as neuropathic pain (acroparesthesias), which is characterized by burning sensations in the arms and legs particularly in heat, cold weather or after exertion. Dermatological manifestations include angiokeratomas, telangiectasias and hypohidrosis. The deposition of Gb3 in the mesenteric blood vessels and autonomic ganglia can cause gastrointestinal disturbances including abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea and vomiting, and constipation. Ocular involvement is also seen with Fabry disease with the formation of capsular cataracts. These cataracts have not been known to impair vision. In the absence of intervention, Fabry disease can progress to severe complications involving the cardiac and renal systems.



The diagnosis of Fabry disease is generally confirmed by biochemical and/or genetic testing including leukocyte alpha-galactosidase activity. Skin biopsy typically reveals high lipid content. Lipids may also be found inside muscle fibers, endothelial cells, and ganglion cells. Although there is no cure for Fabry disease, therapeutic options include enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant alpha-galactosidase and migalastat, a chaperone protein that mobilizes alpha-galactosidase to lysosomes.




Option Analysis

❌ Hexosaminidase:
Incorrect: Tay-Sachs disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase and is characterized by neurodegeneration, developmental delay, and a cherry-red spot in the macula. Peripheral neuropathy and dermatological manifestations are not commonly encountered. Additionally, this patient has attained all developmental milestones appropriately, making this diagnosis less likely.
❌ Glucocerebrosidase:
Incorrect: Glucocerebrosidase is deficient in Gaucher disease. Gaucher disease is characterized by hepatosplenomegaly, osteoporosis, bone crises, along with pancytopenia. Peripheral neuropathy, angiokeratomas and telangiectasias would be unlikely.
❌ Galactocerebrosidase:
Incorrect: Krabbe disease, caused by a deficiency of galactocerebrosidase, does manifest with peripheral neuropathy. However, angiokeratomas are unlikely. Furthermore, most children show signs of profound developmental delay and optic atrophy. The absence of these findings makes this diagnosis unlikely.
✅ α-Galactosidase A:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ α-1,6-glucosidase:
Incorrect: Cori disease is a glycogen storage disease that results from the deficient functioning of the enzyme α-1,6-glucosidase (debranching enzyme). Clinical features include hepatomegaly and severe fasting hypoglycemia. Angiokeratomas and peripheral neuropathy are not typical of this disease.

questions.text:
A 5-month-old girl undergoes evaluation for failure to thrive. The parents are concerned that she is no longer able to sit or roll over on her own, despite being able to a few weeks ago. She was born at term with a birth weight of 2.5-kg (5.5-lb). Her current height and weight are below the 10th percentile, while at her previous visit 2 months ago, she was in the 40th percentile for both. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals marked hypotonia throughout, with decreased deep tendon reflexes noted bilaterally in the upper and lower extremities. Abdominal examination is notable for hepatosplenomegaly. Fundoscopic examination is shown below:



By Achim Fieß, Ömer Cal, Stephan Kehrein, Sven Halstenberg, Inez Frisch, Ulrich Helmut Steinhorst
Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons">Wikimedia Commons

If further testing is performed, which of the following enzymes is most likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is being evaluated for failure to thrive. Her physical examination findings indicate hepatosplenomegaly and a cherry-red spot on the macula, a presentation that is consistent with Niemann-Pick disease, an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease.

Niemann-Pick disease (NPD) results from the inability to break down sphingomyelin, a component of cell membranes due to the deficiency of the enzyme sphingomyelinase. NPD has 3 different genetic variants: Type A, B and C. Type A and B are associated with mutations in the SMPD1 gene, leading to complete and partial absence of sphingomyelinase activity respectively. Type C is caused by a mutation in NPC1 and NPC2 genes. Histologically, lipid-laden macrophages called foam cells reflect the accumulation of sphingomyelin in lysosomes.



Clinical manifestations of NPD are the result of accumulations of sphingomyelin and include hepatosplenomegaly, interstitial lung disease, regression of previously attained developmental milestones, developmental delay, and a cherry-red spot in the macula. The cherry-red spot occurs due to sphingolipid accumulation in the retinal ganglion cells in the perifoveal area, causing the perifoveal area to appear pale, while the fovea, which has no ganglion cells, retains its "cherry red" color. Neurological symptoms are rapid, progressive and carry a poor prognosis, with death by 2-3 years of age. These symptoms include hypotonia, loss of early motor skills, feeding difficulties and areflexia. Specifically, NPD type B is characterized by hyperlipidemia and thrombocytopenia in addition to the findings found in type A. Neurologic symptoms are unlikely in type B.

Diagnosis is made by demonstrating acid sphingomyelinase deficiency in leukocytes from whole blood samples.





Option Analysis

❌ Alpha-galactosidase A:
Incorrect: Fabry disease results in the accumulation of ceramide trihexoside due to the deficiency of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase A. The characteristic features of this disease include acroparesthesias (intermittent neuropathy of the extremities), angiokeratomas, and hypohidrosis. Cherry-red spots on the macula are not seen in this lysosomal storage disease.
❌ Hexosaminidase A:
Incorrect: The clinical manifestations of Tay-Sachs disease are the result of accumulation of GM2 ganglioside due to the deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase. The clinical presentation does include cherry-red spots on the macula and neurodegeneration. However, in contrast to patients with Niemann-Pick disease, patients with Tay-Sachs do not have hepatosplenomegaly; additionally, they are hyperreflexic (as opposed to this patient’s hyporeflexia).
❌ Galactocerebrosidase:
Incorrect: Krabbe disease is associated with the deficiency of the enzyme galactocerebrosidase. It presents with peripheral neuropathy, neurodegeneration, and optic atrophy. Cherry-red spots on the macula and hepatosplenomegaly are not associated with this lysosomal storage disorder.
❌ Glucocerebrosidase:
Incorrect: Glucocerebrosidase is deficient in Gaucher disease, and it manifests with hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, and skeletal manifestations including osteoporosis and avascular necrosis of the femur. Cherry-red macular spots are not likely.
✅ Sphingomyelinase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 1-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of developmental regression and “odd appearance” of his eyes. His parents state he was able to sit up on his own without support until a month ago, when they noticed that he could no longer sit up or roll over. Additionally, his parents state he has had recurrent respiratory infections, and they now notice a chronic nasal discharge. His birth was unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a prominent forehead, flat nose bridge and enlarged lips, gums and tongue. Abdominal examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and an umbilical hernia. Ophthalmic examination is shown below:



Reproduced from Wikipedia


Accumulation of which of the following metabolites is most likely present in this patient’s tissues?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with symptoms of corneal clouding, developmental delay, regression of previously attained developmental milestones, and hepatosplenomegaly, along with characteristic coarse facial features, likely has Hurler syndrome, a lysosomal storage disorder.

Lysosomes are cell organelles that are involved in the breakdown and degradation of complex metabolic products of the cell into simpler components. Lysosomal storage disorders are inborn errors of metabolism that are the result of deficient enzymes involved in the breakdown of cell products, mucopolysaccharides, and glycoproteins. Inappropriate accumulation of these products in cells, specifically in the lysosomes, leads to cell distention and impairment of cell function. Most lysosomal storage disorders are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern and hence are prevalent among Ashkenazi Jew, Amish, and Cajun populations. Hunter syndrome and Fabry disease have an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern.

Hunter and Hurler syndrome are lysosomal storage disorders, specifically mucopolysaccharidosis that involve the accumulation of mucopolysaccharides or glycosaminoglycans (cell wall components) like heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate. Mucopolysaccharidoses are caused by a deficiency of enzymes that break down these glycosaminoglycans. In Hurler syndrome, accumulation of heparan and dermatan sulfate due to a deficiency of alpha-L-iduronidase results in skeletal abnormalities, characteristic facial features (previously known as gargoylism), recurrent upper respiratory infections, airway obstruction, hepatosplenomegaly, and developmental delay.



Sphingolipidoses are another subdivision of lysosomal storage disorders that result from the accumulation of cell membrane sphingolipids, such as sphingomyelin, glucocerebroside, GM2 ganglioside, and galactocerebroside. Diseases included in this class include Tay-Sachs disease, Gaucher disease, Krabbe disease, metachromatic leukodystrophy, Fabry disease, and Niemann-Pick disease.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Heparan sulfate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Galactocerebroside:
Incorrect: Krabbe disease is a liposomal storage disease that results in the abnormal accumulation of galactocerebroside. Children present with developmental delay and optic atrophy, along with symptoms of peripheral neuropathy. Corneal clouding and hepatosplenomegaly are not characteristic features of this disease.
❌ Ceramide trihexoside:
Incorrect: Ceramide trihexoside is the metabolite that accumulates in Fabry disease, which is characterized by dermal manifestations (hypohidrosis, angiokeratosis) and peripheral neuropathy. The absence of these findings makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ GM2 ganglioside:
Incorrect: Tay-Sachs disease results in the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. It is a liposomal storage disease characterized by vision disturbances, cherry-red spot in the macula, and developmental delay. Although this patient has vision disturbances and developmental delay, his ophthalmic examination does not reveal a cherry-red spot, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Sphingomyelin:
Incorrect: Niemann-Pick disease is characterized by hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, and a cherry-red spot on the macula. The absence of these fundoscopic findings makes this diagnosis unlikely. Additionally, the coarse facial features seen in this patient would not be found in Niemann-Pick disease.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room for evaluation of severe hip pain over the past several hours. His parents have noticed that he has begun to walk with a limp due to pain in his right hip over the last 2 weeks, which acutely worsened today. His past medical history is significant for recurrent upper respiratory infections over the past 2 years. The patient has also had multiple episodes of epistaxis over the past year. His birth and developmental history are unremarkable, and his immunizations are up to date. His family is of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Vitals are within normal limits. A complete physical examination is unable to be performed because of irritability and severe hip pain. Complete blood counts are shown below:

 Laboratory value  Result 
Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  8.4 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  2,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  36,000/mm3 

MRI of the right hip reveals avascular necrosis. The physician suspects a genetic disorder. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on further examination?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of avascular necrosis of the hip, history of recurrent infections, and laboratory investigations revealing pancytopenia are suggestive of a diagnosis of Gaucher disease.

Gaucher disease (GD) is an autosomal recessive condition caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. Glucocerebrosidase is an enzyme that breaks down glucocerebroside, a cellular sphingolipid. In its absence, glucocerebroside accumulates in leukocytes, macrophages, spleen, liver, bone marrow, kidney and central nervous system. The accumulation of glucocerebroside in the lysosomes of macrophages results in lipid-laden macrophages that appear like crumpled tissue paper (Gaucher cells).

Clinical manifestations of GD reflect the deposition of glucocerebroside in various tissues and include hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia (due to bone marrow infiltration), osteoporosis and avascular necrosis of the femur. Infiltration of the bone marrow can result in anemia, leukopenia (recurrent infections), and thrombocytopenia (epistaxis, petechiae).

 


Skeletal involvement is particularly important in the presentation of GD, as it is accompanied by a high degree of morbidity. Osteopenia is near universal in GD as a representation of decreased bone mineral density. Patients may present with diffuse bone pain and episodes of acute bone crisis that can progress to osteonecrosis and joint collapse. Other complications include vertebral compression fractures, avascular necrosis of the femur and pathologic fractures. Diagnosis is made by detecting levels of enzyme activity (glucocerebrosidase) in leukocytes of whole blood samples. Treatment involves enzyme replacement therapy.




Option Analysis

✅ Hepatosplenomegaly:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Proteinuria and progressive renal insufficiency:
Incorrect: Proteinuria and renal dysfunction are complications associated with untreated Fabry disease. The initial presentation of Fabry disease involves gastrointestinal disturbances, angiokeratomas and hypohidrosis. The absence of these findings make this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Left ventricular hypertrophy:
Incorrect: Cardiac complications of Fabry disease include left ventricular hypertrophy, HOCM, myocardial fibrosis, valvular abnormalities and conduction defects. The initial presentation of Fabry disease involves gastrointestinal disturbances, angiokeratomas and hypohidrosis. The absence of these findings make this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Cherry-red spot on the macula:
Incorrect: Cherry-red spots on the macula are seen with certain lysosomal storage disorders including Tay-Sachs disease and Niemann-Pick disease. However, neither of these diseases are known to be associated with pancytopenia, as seen in this patient’s CBC.
❌ Angiokeratomas:
Incorrect: Dermatological manifestations including angiokeratomas, telangiectasias, and hypohidrosis, along with peripheral neuropathic pain (acroparesthesias), are characteristic features of Fabry disease. Fabry disease is a lysosomal storage disease with a deficiency of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase. Pancytopenia and joint pain are not features associated with Fabry disease.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is being evaluated for developmental delay. He recently learned to sit up on his own; however, he is unable to stand up without support. His past medical history is significant for recurrent upper respiratory infections. His family is of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Physical examination shows coarse facial features, kyphoscoliosis, and restricted joint mobility. Abdominal examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Ophthalmic examination reveals corneal clouding. A genetic condition is suspected. Which of the following intracellular processes are defective considering the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Phosphorylation of mannose residues in the Golgi apparatus
Beta-oxidation of very long chain fatty acids in peroxisomes
Dynein arm defect leading to immotile cilia

questions.solution:
Inclusion cell (I-cell) disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage. It results from defective functioning of the enzyme phosphotransferase, which is found in the Golgi apparatus. This enzyme transfers phosphate to mannose residues on specific proteins. Proteins with a mannose-6-phosphate are targeted to lysosomes within the cell. Without this marker, proteins are instead secreted outside the cell, which is the default pathway for proteins moving through the Golgi apparatus. Lysosomes cannot function without these proteins, which act as catabolic enzymes for the normal breakdown of substances (e.g., oligosaccharides, lipids, and glycosaminoglycans) in various tissues throughout the body. The lysosomal cellular debris is visualized as inclusion bodies.

Clinical manifestations include severe developmental delays, coarse facial features, clawed deformities, corneal clouding, kyphoscoliosis, gingival hyperplasia, restricted joint mobility, recurrent infections, and high plasma levels of lysosomal enzymes.

Option Analysis

✅ Phosphorylation of mannose residues in the Golgi apparatus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Beta-oxidation of very long chain fatty acids in peroxisomes :
Incorrect: Peroxisomes are organelles that are involved in the metabolism of beta-oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder that results from defective beta-oxidation in peroxisomes. It leads to VLCFA accumulation in the adrenals and in neural tissue, resulting in adrenal crisis and coma. Absence of these findings makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Defective ubiquitin proteasome system :
Incorrect: Ubiquitin is a protein that tags other cellular proteins via an ATP-dependent mechanism for degradation. Ubiquitin-tagged proteins are degraded into smaller peptides by proteasomes. Defective ubiquitin proteasomes systems can contribute to neurodegenerative conditions including Alzheimer disease and Parkinson disease.
❌ Alpha-oxidation in peroxisomes:
Incorrect: Alpha-oxidation is strictly a peroxisomal process. Defective alpha-oxidation is seen in Refsum disease, an autosomal recessive disorder. It manifests with symptoms including ataxia, scaly skin, cataracts and epiphyseal dysplasia. This patient’s coarse facial features, developmental delay, and hepatosplenomegaly are suggestive of a different etiology.
❌ Dynein arm defect leading to immotile cilia:
Incorrect: Immotile cilia due to a dynein arm defect is the pathogenesis leading to Kartagener syndrome. Although patients are known to have a history of recurrent upper respiratory infections including rhinitis and sinusitis due to poor ciliary clearance, findings such as hepatosplenomegaly and developmental delay would not be likely.

questions.text: A 24-year old man presents to his primary care physician’s clinic due to increasing weakness in his legs for the last three years. He notes that his legs feel very stiff. He reports that he had a maternal uncle with similar issues. On physical exam, the patient has decreased vibratory sensation in the bilateral lower extremities. He exhibits signs of early male pattern baldness. The physician confirms the suspected diagnosis via testing the patient’s plasma for accumulated very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) and a mutation in the ABCD1 gene. Which of the following organelles is affected in this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
Peroxisomal disorders are a heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by dysfunction of peroxisomes. Peroxisomes are ubiquitous organelles responsible for β-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) and ɑ-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. They also function in the catabolism of amino acids and alcohol, as well as the synthesis of bile acids, cholesterol, and plasmalogens. Peroxisomal disorders include Zellweger syndrome, Refsum disease, and adrenoleukodystrophy.

Adrenoleukodystrophy results from X-linked recessive mutations in the ABCD1 gene which cause a defect in β-oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs). These VLCFAs accumulate in tissues throughout the body. The tissues most heavily affected include the adrenal glands, myelin in the central nervous system, and Leydig cells in the testes. Over time, deposition of VLCFA in these tissues can lead to clinical features of adrenal crisis, muscle stiffness, sexual dysfunction, as well as progressive paraparesis and ataxia. Over time, progressive demyelination throughout the central nervous system leads to a progressive vegetative state, coma, and death.

Option Analysis

❌ Ribosomes:
Incorrect: Ribosomopathies include Diamond Blackfan anemia, Treacher Collins syndrome, and X-linked dyskeratosis congenita. This patient has adrenoleukodystrophy, which is instead a disease of peroxisomes.  
❌ Golgi apparatus:
Incorrect: The Golgi apparatus is responsible for the secretion and modification of proteins. There are a number of diseases related to disorders of the Golgi apparatus including Wilson disease, Duchenne muscular dystrophy, Parkinson disease, Angelman syndrome, and cutis laxa. This patient has adrenoleukodystrophy, which is instead a disease of peroxisomes.  
❌ Mitochondria:
Incorrect: Examples of mitochondrial diseases include mitochondrial myopathies and Leber hereditary optic neuropathy. This patient has adrenoleukodystrophy, which is instead a disease of peroxisomes.  
✅ Peroxisomes  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lysosomes:
Incorrect: Lysosomal storage diseases lead to a buildup of abnormal metabolic products. These diseases include Tay-Sachs disease, Fabry disease, metachromatic leukodystrophy, Krabbe disease, Gaucher disease, Niemann-Pick disease, Hurler syndrome, and Hunter syndrome. This patient has adrenoleukodystrophy, which is instead a disease of peroxisomes.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of shortness of breath. Previously, she was able to jog several miles per day, but she now becomes out of breath after walking a couple of blocks. The patient has also experienced mild wheezing and a productive cough. Past medical history is insignificant, and the patient does not take any medications. Family history is notable for the death of the patient’s father from liver cirrhosis at a young age. The patient does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 125/65 mmHg. Bilateral rhonchi are heard on lung auscultation. Cardiac examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below:

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Glucose  100 mg/dL 
 Creatinine   0.6 g/dL 
 BUN  10 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)  49 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)  46 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase   100 U/L 

Spirometry is notable for an FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%. Which of the following is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This young woman presents with progressively worsening dyspnea, abnormal liver function tests, and a family history of early-onset liver cirrhosis. She most likely has panacinar emphysema secondary to alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency.

AAT is a serine protease inhibitor generated by the liver to protect organs against unintended collateral damage from proteases, most importantly neutrophil elastase. AAT deficiency is inherited in a co-dominant fashion. Individuals with one or more copies of the mutated gene have misfolding of the AAT protein, which subsequently accumulates within the liver and causes organ damage. Since AAT is trapped within the liver, there is a deficiency of this protein in the lungs, which leads to unchecked elastase activity and widespread destruction of pulmonary elastic tissue. These changes lead to lung hyperinflation and panacinar emphysema, which is characterized by destruction of the entire acinus distal to the respiratory bronchioles.

Clinically, the condition can manifest with early-onset emphysema and liver cirrhosis. Pulmonary symptoms tend to be worse in individuals who smoke, since the smoke induces lung inflammation and further inhibits AAT activity.



Option Analysis

✅ Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pleural effusion:
Incorrect: A pleural effusion is characterized by an abnormal collection of fluid in the pleural space. It can arise due to excess pleural fluid production, decreased pleural fluid absorption, or a combination of these factors. The condition can cause chest pain, dyspnea, cough, and reduced breath sounds. However, a pleural effusion would not account for the elevated liver enzymes.
❌ Cystic fibrosis:
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis causes recurrent pulmonary infections, lung tissue injury and scarring, as well as shortness of breath. However, it would not cause a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. Instead, the pulmonary scarring leads to a restrictive pattern of lung disease and an increased FEV1/FVC ratio.
❌ Asthma:
Incorrect: Asthma is an inflammatory disease of the airways. It is characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and easily triggered bronchospasms. Symptoms include episodes of wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. However, asthma would not account for this patient’s elevated liver enzymes.
❌ Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is characterized by a progressive and irreversible decline in lung function secondary to excess collagen tissue deposition. Symptoms typically include gradual onset of shortness of breath and a dry cough. Since idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease, patients would present with an increased FEV1/FVC ratio (as opposed to the decreased ratio seen in this patient).

questions.text: A 1-year old girl is brought to the pediatrician’s clinic for evaluation of gross motor delay. Her parents are concerned because she has not been able to sit up yet and feels “limp” when they hold her. They report that she has had seizures in the past. Upon physical exam, she has both hypotonia and hepatomegaly. No other family members had similar symptoms during development. Genetic testing is performed, and she is found to have a mutation in the PEX gene. What is the inheritance pattern of the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Peroxisomal disorders are a heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by dysfunction of peroxisomes. Peroxisomes are ubiquitous organelles responsible for β-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) and ɑ-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. They also function in the catabolism of amino acids and alcohol, as well as the synthesis of bile acids, cholesterol, and plasmalogens. Peroxisomal disorders include Zellweger syndrome, Refsum disease, and adrenoleukodystrophy.

Zellweger syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the PEX gene, which encodes for proteins that allow for the normal assembly of peroxisomes. Mutations in this gene ultimately result in accumulation of VLCFAs and branched chain fatty acids in multiple organ systems. In addition, the inability to synthesize plasmalogens results in impaired brain and lung function. Typically, patients present in the first year of life with hypotonia, seizures, and hepatomegaly. Plasma levels of VLCFAs are elevated in these patients, and the diagnosis can be confirmed by genetic testing.

Option Analysis

❌ X-linked dominant  :
Incorrect: X-linked dominant disorders can be inherited through either parent. Affected mothers will transmit the disease to 50% of daughters and sons, whereas affected fathers will transmit the disease to all of their daughters and none of their sons – therefore, there will almost always be a family history of the disorder in a patient’s extended family. Examples of X-linked dominant disorders include Fragile X syndrome, Alport syndrome, and hypophosphatemic rickets. This patient has Zellweger syndrome, which is instead transmitted via an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.
❌ X-linked recessive:
Incorrect: X-linked recessive is the inheritance pattern of adrenoleukodystrophy–a disease characterized by impaired beta-oxidation and accumulation of very long chain fatty acids in the adrenal glands, brain, and testes. X-linked recessive disorders affect 50% of sons of heterozygous mothers. There is no male-to-male transmission observed with X-linked recessive disorders. Other examples of X-linked recessive disorders include Fabry disease, G6PD deficiency, Hunter syndrome, and Lesch-Nyhan. This patient has Zellweger syndrome, which is instead transmitted via an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.
✅ Autosomal recessive:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Autosomal dominant:
Incorrect: In autosomal dominant disorders, when one parent is affected, 50% of the offspring will inherit the gene, and thus there is almost always a family history of the condition. Examples of autosomal dominant diseases include achondroplasia, hereditary spherocytosis, Huntington disease, Marfan syndrome, multiple endocrine neoplasia, neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2, and Von Hippel-Lindau disease. This patient has Zellweger syndrome, which is instead transmitted via an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.  
❌ Mitochondrial  :
Incorrect: Diseases of the mitochondria are inherited only from the mother, and all offspring will demonstrate signs of the disease. Examples of diseases inherited via a mitochondrial inheritance pattern include mitochondrial myopathies and Leber hereditary optic neuropathy. This patient has Zellweger syndrome, which is instead transmitted via an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.
